label: [Katie Thornton et al. case testimonies]: Department of the Interior, Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Chelsea, I. T., June 7, 1901

metadata.label: title
metadata.value: [Katie Thornton et al. case testimonies]: Department of the Interior, Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Chelsea, I. T., June 7, 1901

metadata.label: abstract
metadata.value: Testimonies given on behalf of Katie Thornton, a former enslaved African American, for the enrollment of herself and her two minor children (Millie and Emma) as Cherokee Freedmen. Katie Thornton testifies that she had been enslaved by John Thornton, a Cherokee citizen, and had been taken from Goingsnake District to Fort Scott, Kansas, during the Civil War. She returned in 1866, and testifies that she has lived in the Nation with her children ever since. Her husband Henry, a Cherokee Freedmen, had served in the army until he was discharged after becoming disabled by an injury, and the family moved to Garnett, Kansas. Harry Stills Frank Ross, and Lewis Whitmire, a self-described Cherokee citizen, testify that they had seen her living "on Lightning Creek" in 1866, and that she now lives near "Big Creek" in the Cherokee Nation. They also answer questions about her children, including Maggie Curls, her oldest. Also includes are testimonies of Jack Landrum, on his own behalf, and that of George Bruckner, in response to an objection from  attorney W.W. Hastings to Jack Landrum as a witness. It is found that Katie cannot be identified in 1880 authenticated and 1896 census rolls, but the names of  herself and her two children are listed in the Kern-Clifton roll as living in the Cooweescoowee District. Their case will be listed on a "doubtful card" for further consideration.
